p: The mango peel composition mainly depends on the maturity stage, locality, variety, and climatic conditions in its production region. As shown in Table 1, mango peel contains a variety of macronutrients (total carbohydrates (20–30%), protein, amino acids, lipids, organic acids as well as dietary fiber) and micronutrients. Dietary fiber is an important functional nutrient and its concentration in different mango varieties, ranging between 16% and 28% soluble and 29% and 50% insoluble fiber [ 69]. The content of vitamin C ranges from 188–2570 µg/g, varying widely in different cultivars. Ajila et al. [ 69] reported 188–392 µg/g of vitamin C in both Badami and Raspuri varieties, and higher amounts in the ripened peel compared to the raw peel ( Table 1). The presence of vitamin E (205–509 µg/g) in mango peel led to its use in the preparation of skin care products. The concentration of vitamin E is also higher in ripened mango peel than in raw mango peel ( Table 1). The mango peel contains significantly higher levels than pulp of the following minerals: Ca > K > Mg > Na > Fe > Mn > Zn > Cu [ 70].
